questions.question: What is RAM?
questions.explanation: RAM: volatile fast memory. Speed: nanoseconds access. Purpose: active program storage. Lost: powered off loses all. Capacity: 8-64GB typical. Upgrade: easy typically.

questions.question: What is an HDD?
questions.explanation: HDD: traditional storage device. Speed: slower than SSD. Capacity: large, affordable. Lifespan: 3-5 years typical. Noise: audible operation. Mechanical: can fail physically.

questions.question: What is an SSD?
questions.explanation: SSD: no moving parts storage. Speed: much faster than HDD. Reliability: no mechanical failure. Cost: more expensive per GB. Durability: proven reliable. Becoming: standard nowadays.

questions.question: What is NVMe?
questions.explanation: NVMe: faster than SATA. Speed: GB/s typical. Form factor: M.2 slot. Performance: 4-7x faster than SATA SSD. Cost: slightly more expensive. Adoption: new computers use.

questions.question: What is SATA?
questions.explanation: SATA: older SSD/HDD connector. Speed: limited bandwidth. Compatibility: still widely supported. Cost: cheaper than NVMe. Deprecation: gradually phased out. Legacy: older computers use.

questions.question: What is DDR4?
questions.explanation: DDR4: current RAM standard. Speed: 2133-3200 MHz typical. Voltage: 1.2V reduced. Efficiency: better than DDR3. Replacement: DDR5 emerging. Availability: widely available.

questions.question: What is DDR5?
questions.explanation: DDR5: latest RAM standard. Speed: 4800+ MHz potential. Performance: ~1.3x faster than DDR4. Cost: higher currently. Adoption: increasing in new systems. Future: becoming standard.

questions.question: What is cache memory?
questions.explanation: Cache: ultra-fast small memory. Location: on/near CPU. Levels: L1, L2, L3 typical. Speed: nanoseconds. Purpose: accelerate frequent data access. Importance: performance critical.

questions.question: What is ROM?
questions.explanation: ROM: permanent memory. Content: not erasable normally. Uses: firmware, BIOS storage. Purpose: boot information. Capacity: small typically. Technology: persists powered off.

questions.question: What is flash memory?
questions.explanation: Flash: no moving parts storage. Voltage: erased electrically. Uses: SSDs, USB drives, phones. Speed: fast compared to HDD. Durability: limited write cycles. Technology: semiconductor-based.
